A for atmosphere and friendly staff! :) Such a busily chill place to go-- the chairs are all different, there are little jars of jams all over, everyone buses their own table, and when your order is ready, they happily call your name across the restaurant. 

I got the frittata which came with potatoes and toast, all delish. I was having a hard time deciding about what to get because the pastries looked good too (typically I opt to get one of evvvvvvverything) but when I told the cashier it was my first time there and how excited I was, she gave me not one, but TWO free scones! I picked a walnut-pesto scone, and she was like, "Well, scones are supposed to be sweet, and that one's savory, so have this one, too!" and gave me a lemony cream scone. 

Mmmm. Too much food for one girl to handle, but great leftovers for later. Great vibe, good food, friendly people. It gets busy but is worth hitting up, even to study and drink tea with a scone. 

Hint: they have mimosas! 
Double hint: they do not take credit cards.

Great place for breakfast, this was our first visit. This place is so Madison. I never had an eggplant omelet before and it was wonderful fresh and delicious. The scones were really good as well, some of the best bakery I have ever had. Friendly helpful staff, parking available on the side of the building.

The good: the atmosphere is great. Chalkboard menus, baked goods on display, Christmas decorations already up (nov 2).

The bad: the gingerbread latte was a little bitter. The potatoes were a little dry.

The ugly: my buddy Will that I went with.

Lazy Jane's is delicious! 

The scones are probably one of the best I've ever had, but the brunch/breakfast menu is just as good!

The first time I was at Lazy Jane's I opted for the french toast with fresh berries and real whip cream (real whip cream is already a game changer). It tasted amazing and it was really hard not to just go round two the second time I visited, but I switched it up and went savory with the chorizo scramble. I swear I could eat that every day! 

The coffee is also a win, the atmosphere is chill and comforting, all of which make this an excellent place to ease into your weekend mornings.

PS. Be sure to have cash on hand as they do not accept cards. They do have an ATM at the location, but with a line waiting for this deliciousness, you don't want to have to step out last minute because you are out of cash.

Soooo good.  I'm a sucker for scones over any other pastry and couldn't resist a blueberry one.  It wasn't too sweet and had just the right amount of moisture.  The scone definitely has a lemon flavour but it compliments the blueberries loaded in the treat.  The density was perfect and the icing/glaze wasn't overpowering.  It's making my current bus ride to Minneapolis bearable.

I also had a quick sandwich (I've already forgotten its actual name...) but it was egg, sausage, and cheese open-faced on a larger than average English muffin.  Filled me up for the morning and the egg wasn't overcooked.  Solid.  

The folks working were friendly, quick, and extremely flexible.  A long line had formed by the time my friend and I got there but we were helped in no time.

I have been to Lazy Janes many times and enjoyed each experience! First of all the ambience is very cute as the restaurant is located in an old house on Willy street and filled with interesting knick knacks and furniture. You order at the counter and it is self serve for silverware and water. At peak time this can cause some congestion. They now take credit cards.

While Lazy Janes is most known for their breakfast and scones, I am more of a lunch kind of person. I tend to get the soup and sandwich combo. Their tomato basil soup is so good. Very rich with nice chunks of tomatoes. I haven't had a sandwich of theirs I didn't like. I especially like the grilled cheese with delicious bread and smooth avocado to bring out the flavor of the cheese.

If you are looking for a delicious and eclectic lunch or breakfast option, be sure to check out Lazy Janes!

Best scones I've ever had. Can't speak for the breakfast in the main bldg, but I stopped by yesterday to the "annex" for coffee and scones to go. I got the banana chocolate chip, orange coconut white chocolate, and cherry lemon creme ones. Wow. Wow. Wow. 

And on top of it all, the staff are so friendly. This place epitomizes what Madison is all about- top-notch quality and top-notch people, with a pleasant touch of hippie :)

By far my favorite place for breakfast and brunch in Madison. Nothing compares to Lazy Jane's in terms of price, quality or atmosphere. 

Atmosphere - old 2 story house turned into a restaurant. Seating on the 1st and 2nd floor. Old mix of tables, chairs and couches to sit on. Menu is on the wall, you order at the counter, and when your food is ready the kitchen hollers out your name and you pick up your own food at the window. 

Staff - friendly hipster staff that always has a good suggestion on food. I have yet to be steered wrong. 

Coffee - free refills at counter. Just walk up and they will take care of you. 

Food - i have yet to have anything bad here. They have good vegetarian and vegan options as well. My all time favorite dish there is the Biscuits and Gravy. Its probably the best biscuits and gravy north of the Mason Dixon line. What makes ti so good? It's those "holy cow" biscuits. 

Desserts - Get a half dozen scones to go. Try one of each flavor. They are out of this world. They are made fresh daily and are probably the best scones i have ever had. 

Thank god the lazy undergrads refuse to come here for brunch. They are content with walking to Mickey's Dairy bar and we should all be happy about it, because if they ever discover this place en mass, the line will quadruple.
Great local spot.  Seating can be a bit of a problem and the line for ordering gets pretty congested on the weekends - just FYI.  Tasty foodstuffs.  Best hot cocoa in Madison.

This place has my favorite grilled cheese avocado sandwich. It's made sourdough bread with the perfect crunch. The sandwich comes with tomato, red onion, avocado and cheese (sorry I don't remember what kinds of cheese!) I love the salad they serve with the sandwich, it's a simple green salad with some kind of basil dressing...yummmm! It also comes with kettle chips. They now accept credit cards here!!!! Yay!!!!

The hype is real! This place is beyond yummy! So first off, you order before you sit down. I ordered the berries and cream waffle - by far the best fluffiest waffle I have ever had. It must be the batter. It must be the berries. I can't seem to pinpoint what it is, but it's worth the try. I ended up only eating half and saving the rest for later. The blueberry pancake was huge with juicy blueberries. I also ordered the works with a sausage patty and sourdough toast. No complaints whatsoever. 

The decor inside is lovely and vintage. I love the hallway stairs that go up to their second floor right when you walk in because of the beautiful gold hanging mirrors. 

The service was excellent and I cannot wait to return and try their scones.
Lazy Jane's is a gem. Good food, great atmosphere, the perfect breakfast place on Willy St.

I needed a quick lunch a month ago, and hadn't been to lazy jane's in years. I stopped in, and was quickly disappointed to hear they were having hood problems and could not serve me a hot sandwich.

The counter helper recommended the Chicken Salad sandwich since they could only do cold sandwiches. I dislike chicken salad, but was easily persuaded. I have thought about that sandwich ever since that day. I look forward to picking one up again soon.

Great space for eating, especially upstairs. One of the best places in Madison to meet a friend for tea or coffee and talk. The veggie rueben is a surprise hit, expertly done and very filling. The 'real' rueben is also good, but actually not as good as their seitan rendition. The med plate is a generous portion of Wisconsin white-bread preparation. It's not bad, it's just really far from authentic. Breakfast here is pretty good.

The big attraction are the scones, which for my money are the best scones in Madison. Large, filling, delicious, and moist. 

It gets very busy here on the weekends but on most weekdays if you catch them at the tail-end of lunch you'll have a couple hours of comfortable open space in which to hang out, work, and eat.

We had a great breakfast here.  The coffee was piping hot and fantastic.  The eggs were cooked perfectly, and the Yukon gold breakfast taters were cooked and seasoned excellently.  Yummy bread for the toast and the jams were delish.  Way to go

We were on Willy Street today.  Seemed like a good opportunity to try Lazy Janes.  So we did.  We asked the lady behind the register (owner? Manager?) for her favorites

She mentioned the avocado grilled cheese and a Rueben.  So that's what we had

And a blueberry scone.  She told us the sandwiches would come with a side salad with house basil dressing and chips.

We paid and sat down at a table after picking up some flatware and a couple glasses of water.

The food was quite good.  Good suggestions.  If I had a criticism it would be that the kettle chips were a bit too salty.

The scone had a lemony glaze.  Yummy!

Definitely worth another lunch.

I don't know how I haven't reviewed Lazy Janes yet. SCONES. SO MUCH HAPPY.

It's one of my favorite, favorite brunch places in Madison. Super low key (choose your own seat, get your own silverware, pick up your meal, bus your own table... you get the idea), delicious food, bottomless iced tea.. YAY. I enjoy ordering off their specials board because I get the most awesome things there! They had a spinach omelette with pesto and it was unreal, some other scramble type options that have been just great. I love their on-the-menu chorizo scramble too, so it's not just the specials! Their potatoes are so good, too. Nicely sized and seasoned.

Now that they also take credit cards, it's basically a perfect place.

My only qualm--the lines. Whew, you can wait for a while to order, and a while for the food. Overall worth it, but I hesitate coming here after 10am on the weekends.
The scones here were really tasty.  The wait was not too long, and we went prime time on a Saturday morning.  The portions were large and the prices were reasonable.  Service with a smile.

The wait is worth it for the scones alone. Sweet or Savory any flavor. Their lemon scones are a taste of summer that never fades away... a ray of sunshine in every bite. 
Your going to want to pick up extra for later.  CASH ONLY!

My new favorite breakfast place in Madison! I love it! The scones are amazing, as is the what looks like homemade jam. I had the SCC - scrambled eggs and cream cheese and chives. YUM! Great eastside atmosphere and just a cozy, homey feel.

I visited this summer so I can't be too detailed-my memory sucks-but I definitely remember being satiated and pleased afterwards. I ended up getting two different full entres because I was on vacation and quit judging. Everything tasted fresh and well-seasoned. The coffee was also spectacular. It's a cozy place, reminded me of the anti-Starbucks. My only qualm would be the coffee refills, you have to get someone's attention from the kitchen to do it, which can prove awkward when it's busy.
They ask for gratuity at the register, then you bus your own table.  The food isn't super expensive, nor super good.  Nah....

Hmm, I would really say this is around 3.5 stars.

As the co-owner of a pastry shop, I don't eat baked goods nearly enough. Not because we make any, because we don't, but because I try to pretend to eat healthy foods outside of work. I need to stop doing this, because you know what- baked goods are tasty. And Lazy Jane's are top, top notch.

The boyfriend had the morning bun (with sugar) and i had a blueberry scone. Both were deeeee-lish. The scone was rather moist (for a scone) with a slight lemony flavor.  The morning bun was like cinnamon sugar-dusted crack. Flaky and sweet, crusty on the outside, soft on the inside, pretty much perfect. And that was just to start!

I attempted to have a healthy breakfast and went with the granola with berries, bananas, and yogurt. The granola was pretty good, but the berries were frozen- rather, defrosted frozen berries. Which I guess is better than fresh berries in October, since berries are obviously out of season, but some of them were still partially frozen, and that just seems a little. . . cheap? I would have preferred something seasonal, like apples. Ooh- warm baked apples with granola and yogurt! That would have been good.

Boyfriend had a fritatta, his sister had some kind of scramble. He said his could have been a touch saltier.  

Good coffee, cute, homey atmosphere.  It's out of the way, so while it IS crowded, it's not teeming with college kids. So, that's good.

I have been here twice so far, love this cozy family style coffee house. It is a good place to gather together with friends and family. I love their scones the best! So many selections, always crowded!

Today I woke up at 8am so I could get in to Lazy Jane's.  I should have slept in.

I tried their special of Biscuits and Gravy with two eggs.  The gravy tasted very greasy and had no depth.  It was just sausage gravy. I pepped it myself but otherwise it was bland.  The biscuits were SO dense. I could have used another side of gravy to soak them up. I live by the motto, no biscuit left behind.  Today, I had to leave one behind.  I left breakfast with an overall feeling of mediocrity.  I am so sad by this.

I tried my husband's breakfast potatoes. Also a disappointment. They alternated between cold and burnt. 

I probably will not be back.

Food is great... atmosphere is noisy but fun.... if there is a line (those in the know go in the side door and grab a table while others wait to order their food - otherwise you will never get one!)  

Some items on the menu due tend to run out.... especially if they are fresh.

I like Lazy Jane's--a lot.  Their scones are contenders for the coveted title of "Best Scones in the World."  Particularly the cherry scones.  The other place is Oakhouse Bakery.   The rest of the food is good, too, but nothing I've had there can hold a candle to the scones.  I love the atmosphere very much, as well.

I'm not a fan of the line to order, the fact that they don't accept cards (yes, they do have an ATM), and that you have to sit down to wait for your order (if there's a place to sit, mind you!)--which might be upstairs--and they yell your name for you to come get it.  That's not so much my thing.  I prefer to have a conversation and not worry about whether they just said "Heather" or "Hector" (or even "Richard") over the din of the customers when I'm sitting upstairs.

I do come back here pretty regularly for their seitan hash.  The atmosphere is charming and a nice place to bring out of town guests.

I don't know that I'd call it my favorite breakfast place in town, but it's definitely a regular stop for me.

Aaaaah, the ol' LJ! I have been going here for a few years. I tend to avoid the Saturday and Sunday morning rush because we live in Wisconsin and I haven't been a fan of the cold weather.  However, wanting to eat on Willy St. seems to come with the price of standing and waiting outside more and more these days.  Some even say that standing is good for you... we'll see.  So, I would love for them to find a way around that use line, and I prefer to tip AFTER I get my services instead of right when I pay, but that's about it for the downsides.  LJ has bakery that is amazing and always there to temp you while you are waiting in line, and their food quality is always consistent, which is consistently appreciated. :-) I love me some thick bacon, breakfast potatoes and cheesy grits! There aren't a lot of places that offer up some grits these days, so I have to get them every single time... even if I know that I don't have room in my belly. Lastly, I miss the days when they would call out one's name when your food was ready.  They seem to have mainstreamed it with those coaster buzzers. Luckily I wasn't just going there to have someone yell my name out into a restaurant, so I will be okay.  Long story short: try it!

Another great breakfast/brunch place in downtown Madison. I tried the bagelwich, which was a special item listed the time we were there. I was expecting something pretty basic, and it was, except it was twice as big! Potatoes were great, the bagel sandwich was great, but the best part about this place? The Leonaidus reincarnate cook downstairs yelling everyone's names when their food's ready.

It's love at first visit. Cute, homey decor AND delicious food?! I walked in expecting a very tiny, average looking space, but found so much more. Lazy Janes has about 25 seats downstairs and even more upstairs. This was quite enough for my needs at 2:30 on a Thursday, but I can see how it might be an issue on weekends. It looks like a sweet little cottage and is decorated accordingly. I got the tuna salad sandwich on a croissant and was pleasantly surprised by the quality and the portion size. The croissant was so flakey and buttery I COULD DIE. The side salad was pretty large and covered in a very delicious, clearly homemade dressing. Good sign, since I'm picky bout dressings! The potato chips were absolutely fab. And I just loved sitting there in the window light surrounded by a couple pairs of older ladies! Some cafes have intimidating clientele, especially in the hipster Willy St. neighborhood, but this one really did feel welcoming. This is my kinda cafe! Wish I discovered its wonders earlier. I'll be back for one of those famous scones.

Wonderful! Great food comes out fast. Excellent atmosphere for working, meeting friends, enjoying breakfast/lunch, reading, or just lounging with a cup of coffee. Delightful service :) For the quality of food and location, the prices surprised me - very affordable.

Lazy Jane's is just what everyone needs on a Sunday morning. The setting is adorable and very homey. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars and not 5 is because it was very hard to find seating. I would recommend going here if you have plenty of time to sit down and eat. 

I got the blueberry scone and chorizo scrambler.
The blueberry scone-WOW is all I have to say. As a person who is not a huge fan of sweet things for breakfast-Lazy Jane's scones changed my perspective on that forever. The scone crumbled perfectly when taking a bite and was burst with flavor when eating the blueberries. 

Chorizo scrambler with wheat berry toast- Nicely made. As a person who always likes a little spice in my meals, this was perfect for me. The chorizo and eggs blended nicely and the sweetness of the toast balanced the savory chorizo and eggs.

I really don't know what it is about Lazy Jane's. The antique-looking, house-shaped cafe doesn't have anything special on their menu; they mainly have very traditional American breakfast items as well as some pastries. There are no unique gimmicks unlike a lot of other popular Madison brunch menus. Somehow, they stand out by quality alone.

If I had to guess what Lazy Jane's secret it, I would have to guess butter. Their pancakes are so soft and chewy with a distinct buttery richness to them. Their biscuits have a crisp crust but a soft, buttery interior with the right amount of saltiness. Their scones are more dense than your typical scone. Even their scrambled eggs taste buttery compared to the ones I make at home. It's all delicious!

If you want to get your hands on this delicious brunch, be ready to wake up early or wait in line. I didn't have to wait when I went around 9 am or when I went near closing at 1 pm if that helps you plan your attack. Good luck!
Pretty much the best place to get a morning bun that I can currently think of.

The best scones in town!!  Despite my 5 stars I do have a gripe.  Every time I head in there on a weekend the line is out the door and the place is uncomfortably packed in like sardines.  This can only be a testament to how loved Lazy Jane's really is.  I'm just selfish because I want this fab little place to my whole self!  Xo!  If visiting Madison, this place is a must!  The food is delish!  The scones are out of this world!  You'll feel like you've had a cozy breakfast at your nana's house!  :)

Best. Scones. Ever. I love the strawberry-peach (so does everyone else; they sell out pretty early). Great breakfasts and lunches, too. My one beef: the orange juice is from concentrate! Ruins a perfectly good breakfast.

Best scones! All of their scones have a lemony base that I love. I take them home with me when I visit nearby family. The specials are reliably good and the service is very friendly. I appreciate that they have unlimited coffee refills and large water coolers on both floors to serve yourself. A very enjoyable brunch experience.

I loved Lazy Jane's! I felt like going meatless and ordered the seitan hash. It was flavorful and light, not greasy. The homey, mismatched decor is right up my alley as well. You have to try a scone, they are some of the best ever! The girl working was super friendly and helpful. I wish I could say the same about the other customers waiting in line. You will have to wait in line on a weekend, but it is worth it. Cash only, order and pay at the counter.
Lucky us!!! Line on a Saturday morning at 10 am was short and sweet. Haven't been to Madison for a while and every trip REQUIRES scones. So good. And. Which. By the way. Have gotten even bigger!!

I came here as part of a brunch group, except that we arrived too late for brunch and got lunch instead. Being enmeshed both physically and culturally within the Willy Street community, I had high hopes and expectations, having had excellent experiences in neighboring establishments. Aesthetically, Lazy Jane's is perfect for the quirky disestablishmentarian feel - "cozy hipsterism" - with its tchotchkes on the counter, its mismatching plates, and its cash only policy. I was pretty excited to see that they had artichoke melts, so I got that with a cup of tomato and basil soup. This artichoke melt is very different from all of the other artichoke melt's I've ever had, and I've had plenty. You're supposed to smother the bread in mayonnaise, which they didn't. Also their tomato and basil soup was made with chunks of tomatoes instead of the tomato puree that one would traditionally dip grilled cheese sandwiches into. While the food isn't bad, I feel like the cooks make their food based on what they think it's supposed to be. "Tomato and basil soup? OK let's see...throw some chunks of tomatoes and basil...salt and pepper...hmm maybe some cream to thicken it? Done!" However, I was more confused than delighted by their unusual spins on these classics.

Maybe 3 1/2.   Lemon creme scone I love you!   It's loud, crowded, and you *will* wait on a weekend.  The service is also inconsistent as my ticket has been lost on two occasions (once they gave me a gift certificate to replace it after the 30 minute wait for my food!).  After a few years I've decided to skip the full on breakfast unless it's on a cold and snowy Tuesday  and go for the scones and coffee.

I visited Lazy Janes for the first time this weekend for breakfast. I heard lots of good things about the food and that didn't disappoint. If you've never been to Lazy Janes it looks and feels like a house that has turned into a small quaint restaurant. You order at the front, grab a buzzer and find a spot to sit. Then when your food is done, you go up to the window to grab it. You also clean up after yourself and out your dishes in a tub. 

I had the eggs, bacon and breakfast potatoes. I substituted the toast for a blueberry pancake. Everything was very good. My brother had a corn beef egg combo. He thought it was filling and delicious as well. I'll definitely go back if I'm looking for a hearty American style breakfast!

I went to school at UW-Madison and this was one of my favorite brunch places in town. The service is good. Sometimes the wait was a little longer. However, the food definitely more than makes up for it! I always try to go here for brunch whenever I'm in town.

Do you ever wake up feeling like you want to have a great breakfast but also want to put zero effort in actually making it? When you're a broke college student that sounds like wishful thinking until you find a place like Lazy Jane's. 
I searched on Yelp for breakfasts near me and Lazy Jane's came up as one of the options. Not only, it had my mouth watered with scrumptious food pictures but also seemed very appealing with that two $$ sign on its bio. Only that kind of introduction would make me jump off of my bed early Saturday morning. 
I went to Lazy Jane's right away and I ordered a seitan scrambler and a lemon scone. It was literally one of the best food I have ever had in this town. It was fresh, tasty and timely. Honestly, nothing about this place is lazy like its name. ha! The food was quick, the interior of this cute place was so soothing for the eyes and home cooked food immediately won my heart. 

Overall the breakfast was hearty and delicious. 

*Pro Tip*: Get there a bit early and GET scones. The best you will ever have.

I wish I were more of a morning person, because I'd be more apt to frequent LJ's. The early bird definitely gets the worm in this case...or at least doesn't have to wait in line for eons. This place is always hoppin', hungry people come in droves.

I LOVE the SCC(eggs with scallions and cream cheese), and their scones are too pretty to eat--okay, who am I kidding. They are lovely, though. 

Don't expect a mellow, quiet morning spot. Between the comers and goers, the cooks shouting the names of customers when their order is up, it's craziness. Fun, frantic craziness. A must try!

What a cute, cozy little breakfast cafe!

They serve an assortment of breakfast and lunch dishes, including several vegetarian and vegan dishes. Portion sizes are generous and will fill you up.

Their scones are delightful, never dry, and they're big enough to share!

Yes, the line on the weekends can stretch out the door but you can't go wrong with anything you decide to order at Lazy Jane's.  Special shout out to all of their bakery items with their scones being the best sold anywhere in Madison proper.  Order at the counter and grab a seat.  Wait to hear your name called and dig in.  Great neighborhood spot with home cooked food.

I'm so very happy that Lazy Jane's is walkable for me! We bring all of our visiting friends and family here for the atmosphere, food and consistency.

Here's a typical weekend brunch visit (weekday mornings are super low key):

1. Arrive at a line out the door! Patiently observe the decor as you move inside. The staircase at the door leads up to the dining room.
2. Have your cash ready! Cash only, but there is an ATM. (Leave a tip in the jar!)
3. Pick a scone to nibble on while you wait for your breakfast. In my experience, the estimated wait time is an over-estimation. "30 minutes" was actually about 20 for us.
4. When you order coffee (which is delicious), you'll get one free refill.
5. If you'd like water, there are water coolers upstairs and downstairs with small glasses so you can serve yourself.
6. You'll be given a pager for when your food is ready (at less busy times, they'll shout whatever name you give them!)
7. The upstairs dining room is super cozy! Reminds me of being in an old (kind of run down) bed and breakfast. But totally charming!
8. When your buzzer goes off (or name is bellowed!) you can head over to the window and claim your meal. 
9. Be prepared for an awesome, generously portioned breakfast. I can never finish my food. Eggs and potatoes are not gourmet, but they are not greasy or sloppy like some diner-style breakfasts. Everything is always juuuuuuust riiiight.
10. Clean up your table and carry your dirties to a bus tub. It's the polite thing to do :)

The guys and gals who work the register are always beyond friendly. You can personalize your meat, toast & coffee choices. You'll leave satisfied and cheerful! At least I always do :)

I recently had the pleasure of experiencing Lazy Jane on my trip to Madison, and I'm so glad that I made the trip to the east side to have brunch at this wonderful place. The line was out the door when I arrived, and it does take a while to make your way to the counter to order if that is the case. However, the service was incredibly friendly, and I enjoyed looking at all of the scrumptious baked goods and scones on my way to the cash register. 

I chose the chorizo scramble. It was amazing, and the portions were so large that I could not finish it. There were so many creative dishes to choose from, but I was certainly happy with this one.

The space is like a cute charming old house, and I enjoyed reading the New York Times while I had my coffee and breakfast. Kudos for the coffee refills too!
I guess it's a fine place if you are looking for vegan options. Not a place I'd come back to

I love everything about Lazy Janes!  The staff are awesome, friendly and hilarious!  They have the best scones in Madison!!! My personal favorite is the lemon scone...mmmmmm. Fortunately I live a block away and can walk there whenever I crave their coffee!!!

Busy, busy place. Good food. Old rustic building like a large home opened up. I was alone so after standing in line for 15 min. Headed upstairs to find an open table by the window, drink my coffee (refills but have to go get yourself) & read my book. It took 20-30 min so glad I had a book. They call your name & you go pick up your food. I liked the place & the food.  If your coming with a larger group it may become hard to find a table. I suggest you find the times they are not so busy or spread your group out to take the first large table open. Then text.
Don't tell anyone but the primary reason I visit Madison is to eat the scones at Lazy Jane's.  The fact that my son also lives there? Coincidence.
The scones are delicious and the grilled cheese is buttery with the perfect amount of crunchiness and chewiness. But seriously, you need to get yourself a scone. Do it.

Back in June, I was spending a night in Madison on my way back to Chicago and put out a call on Twitter for suggestions of places to eat breakfast while I was there. When all four of the people I specifically asked suggested Lazy Jane's, I knew that was the place to go. I was absolutely won over by every aspect of this place.

The cafe itself was totally adorable, and the staff was super friendly. I loved the mismatched plates and silverware. The whole place had a very cozy, eclectic feel to it. And nothing makes you feel more welcome in a new restaurant then when they give you free food!  That's right, if you've never been to Lazy Jane's before they give you a few scone.

The food was delicious. I played it safe with the eggs, potatoes, and toast, but in retrospect, I wish I'd been a bit more adventurous. The breakfast potatoes were fabulous - and I'm VERY picky about my breakfast potatoes - and the scones were absolutely out of this world! We actually stopped at the bakery next door to pick up a couple to take back to Chicago with us.

I hear this place gets pretty crowded on the weekends, and I can understand why. However, it was only about half full, and there was no line, when we arrived about 9:30 Sunday morning. I chalked this up to fate, luck and the fact that the street it's on was totally torn up at the time.

I definitely understand why it was a unanimous suggestion among my friends.

This is such a cute and quirky lunch place - if you are in the area, you should check out this cute cafe!! They serve really great tea and coffee, as well as delicious soups and sandwiches. The decor and layout of the place is also fun. Great little gem!

One of my all time favorite breakfast spots in Madison. It has a very cute eclectic vibe which matches Willy street perfectly. You line up to order and then find a seat after so there's never a wait for a spot. The breakfast food itself is fine pretty traditional, but the real standout is the baked goods. You absolutely cannot leave lazy Jones without a pastry of some kind. My all time favorites are their scones the blackberrry in particular, but all the flavors are great. If you're looking for a low-key affordable spot with consistently good food and outstanding pastries this is the spot

First of all, I'm a little biased because I love breakfast food so much.  A restaurant really has to f up for me to rate a breakfast place poorly.  :)

My roomie and I have been talking about eating here for like over a year now and we finally did it this morning! Hurray!!!  Lazy Jane's is quite possibly the most adorable place I've ever eaten at.  Very homey and welcoming.   Also, they give you a free scone if it's your first time there!!!!  (We got ours to go and I have yet to eat my Blackberry scone because I'm still full from breakfast).   

I got The Works (eggs, potatoes, toast, bacon)....delish.  My roomie got their banana cream waffles...amazing.

Will definitely go back!

Edit: omg, by far the best scone ever.

The year is 2049. Some character, whose name we will not mention, is contently leading a life of spinsterhood with cats, knitted afghans, mismatching chairs, endless scones and peanut butter hot cocoa. If this spinster were to own a home it would be that of Lazy Jane's. She would join her friends for a veggie-friendly breakfast with dishes like tofu scramble with siracha and veggies. Her most difficult decision of the day would be blackberry jam or marmalade? 

While the crew waits for their number to be called they'd dote on the precious tableside decor like state plates and vintage ketchup and mustard containers. Nameless spinster would people-watch the room full of treehugging Madisonians and hipster college students with a curious yet confused eye. In the end she would be full from her subpar tofu scramble but seriously contemplating a second order of the peanut butter hot cocoa because it was the sexiest experience she'd had in a while.
Wonderful place to have a brunch. Very cosy and family friendly. Amazing options for a fulfilling meal. I love the atmosphere that makes me feel like at grannies'.

Excellent place for brunch or breakfast, very reasonable prices! The bus yourself thing can be a hassle if you don't hear your name called, but if you're upstairs they just yell louder!!!
The scones are pretty tasty, especially onced smothered with jam! I'd definitely recommend eating here to anyone looking for cheap meal and some unusual atmosphere.

I work a few blocks from Lazy Jane's.  I recently went for the first time and have since gone back twice, but only for lunch.  The first two visits I got their Cheeseburger which is very tasty.  It's cooked however you want and served with Lettuce, Tomato, Onion (grilled or raw) on Ciabatta.  It's served with kettle chips and a side salad for only $7.50.  I highly recommend it. 

The most recent visit, I actually ordered take out and got their Rueben, which I must say ranks pretty highly in my book as a quality rueben sandwich.

It's a nice little restaurant, with good food, a casual atmosphere, and reasonable prices.

I'll be visiting many more times in the future.

I loved LJ's when they first opened.  My friends and I went there several times a week.  But over the years, the prices have tripled (understandably), and the quality/quantity has gone WAY down.  Frankly, it's just not worth the wait any longer- unless you're there for a lemon scone.  Those are.
Great breakfast joint!  This has become mine and my husband's top breakfast joints on the weekend.  Be prepared to stand in line, but it's worth it.

Unfortunately I have nothing new to say other than the fact that I LOVE this little cafe. They now accept credit cards so that is a huge plus! However, it never deterred me before. Their scones are the best I've ever had; it's an absolute must for first timers. Otherwise, they often have great specials so keep an eye out for those too. Their breakfast options are top notch as well as their lunch--my personal favorites are the waffles with berries and the turkey sandwich. I have never gotten anything I didn't like. Way to go!

I love Lazy Jane's. I wish I had the resources to go there every other day. The staff is awesome. They are always super nice and accommodating. 

The food is fabulous. The waffles are my favorite. The potatoes are my favorite in Madison. And of course the scones are awesome. 

The only bad thing I can say about Lazy's is that the bacon has a weird consistency.

PEANUT BUTTER MOCHAS ARE FABULOUS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

My favorite bakery in Madison! The baked goods are perfection and they even have delicious coffee. A lot of times bakeries focus only on the food and have bad coffee and I love my coffee in the morning! Every baked good I have had here has been good but the morning buns are my favorite. If you go here you HAVE to try a morning bun!!

I love, and always will love, Lazy Jane's. Their lemon scones have brought me back to Madison every year since moving to New Orleans and now Seattle. Delicious coffee and amazing other entries! They are always slammed, but it is 100% worth the wait.

We came for the scones, but ended up getting those to go and staying for a breakfast sandwich. The staff were very friendly, the inside is uniquely decorated, and service was fast (although it was a Tuesday morning). Overall a great place for a casual breakfast!

We could have bumped our rating to a 4, but certain circumstances brought our rating down to a 3, which is too bad because the food is pretty good.  The lemon cream scone was incredible.  It isn't super dry like your typical scone and it is full of flavor.  Put some of the raspberry jam provided and you're set.  The BLTP (the "p" is for red bell pepper) was very tasty.  I like how they put it on rye, which adds some additional flavor.  Lots of bacon and surprisingly fresh lettuce (though it did keep falling out because they used the very small inside pieces of a head of romaine).  The red bell pepper was slightly roasted, but I think that it could have spent another minute or two in the broiler to maximize the flavor.  We also had the Works, with eggs, bacon, fried potatoes, and toast.  Again, good but not the best.

While the food deserves a 4 (although the lemonade had little flavor--not tart or sweet... just tasted like unripe lemon and water), everything else about our experience could have brought our rating down.  First of all, it is really inconvenient to go up to the counter and order, especially since the place is so small.  Also, although we saw the sign that said that breakfast on the weekends is served until 2, we didn't see the sign (if there was one) that said that ONLY breakfast was served on the weekend.  And lastly, although I thought the staff was sweet, the crowd was pretty snobbish.  We came with our kids, one of whom is 2 years  old and the other being 2 months old, and people seemed to give us the stink-eye when we had to tell our son to sit down or when our daughter cried for a few minutes (for this instance, we were in line ordering, and the place was so cramped we could hardly put her carrier down and soothe her until we sat down).

We'll come in again for some take out pastries or a quick snack, but this place is a bit overrated.  For a good breakfast/brunch we'll go to Cafe Soleil.  Or Crema Cafe.  Or Mermaid Cafe.  Or Manna Bakery.  Or Monty's.

A favorite for breakfast or brunch when friends or family are visiting.

They have *numerous* options for the vegetarian crowd, a fair number of vegan options, and their gluten-free lemon scones are still my favorite out there.

Super-friendly staff, homey atmosphere, and delicious food.

The only "negatives" I'd give them are that they're always *insanely* busy, and they're an option best when you're dining in a group of 4 or less, unless your party doesn't mind sitting at multiple tables.

Great scones and decent food.  I've never had anything besides the scones that are particularly memorable.  While I kind of like the call-out-your name system of food (it does have some charm), when "joe schmoe" doesn't show up for a while, it starts to lose its charm.  And the one cup refill on coffee (which is of course behind the counter) just seems a little stingy...it's okay lazy jane's, someone taking that extra cup or two won't run you out of business.  Tea is all bagged, unlike the loose offered at other superior breakfast locations in the city.  

Best bet for this joint: buy a scone or two and leave.  Repeat as desired.

FINALLY FINALLY, after SIX years of living in Madison I finally get a chance to eat here, without having to wait in the line that usually goes out the door and halfway down the block. Of course, we had to come super early, but it was worth it! The spicy mac n cheese pancakes are really as good as everyone says. I would definitely share with this plate though. One order fed 4 of us! But the real winner is the Loco Scramble...if you can, ask for extra guacamole. They make the most amazing guac........it's so good. Just soooo creamy, a bit of a spicy kick and packed full of flavor! The service was okay, it's more of a self-serve/clean place, which is fine by me! The only downside is that they only take cash...unless they have changed that by now.

Lazy Jane's is a cool, two-story house in Madison's hip Williamson Street area. It serves an eclectic crowd and offers American breakfast and lunch standards, from hash to veggie melts. When your order is ready the line cook theatrically yells out your name.

There aren't many vegan options, and they rarely have vegan baked goods, but what they do offer for vegans is pretty tasty.

I had the seitan hash ($6.50) which normally comes with eggs, but they left it off for me. Oddly enough, Lazy Jane's doesn't seem to offer a tofu scramble. How can you have seitan but not tofu?

The dish consists of a HUGE amount of skillet potatoes, roasted red peppers, mini pieces of broccoli, and chunks of seitan. The portion size was easily enough for two very filling meals.

I thought the flavors were great, and the toasted sourdough-rye bread on the side was fresh and delicious (Lazy Jane's has two vegan bread options which they helpfully pointed out to me). In general, I think the dish was good, and of much higher quality than similar brunch-style dishes you'd find at Monty's Blue Plate Diner down the road. That said, Monty's has many more vegan offerings than Lazy Jane's, so what you trade in quality you get back in variety.

I'd return to Lazy Jane's to try their limited vegan lunch options, but I just wish they'd expand their offerings to make them THE place to go for vegan brunch and lunch.

Yup, i'm keeping my ambiguous 3.5 star rating. 
I just don't go ecstatic about L-Jane's. 
Coffee is ok, the scones (and by now, I've tried most of the flavors), the atmosphere, and most importantly, the tofu scrambles are all - 'alright.'
There's nothing particularly wrong about their offerings, but none jumps out as the exception. I certainly don't wake up thinking about Lazy Jane's bk. 
I'll keep trying, and hopefully, they'll do the same, too.

Best breakfast and atmosphere in Madison. Hands down.

Always busy, yet still rockin' it. Keep up the amazing work.

Everything from their classic breakfasts to their waffles, spot on.

Refills on coffees is great. 

I could sit here all day.

Sconetastic. Sconerific. Sconemania. Ermegerd, the scones. Great Scott, have you tried the scones??? If you haven't, I feel so sorry for you that I might buy and personally deliver some. No one should live a life in Madison without sampling them at least once. If you lined up all the great things about Willy St. food, they would lead the parade.

If the scones aren't enough, or somehow aren't your thing, come anyway for the eclectic, grandma's house meets yard sale vibe. Even in a room full of strangers, you feel like you're at a sleepover at a best friend's house where their parents are slightly off kilter. Those were always the best parties. You kind of expect the adults to be playing euchre, drinking beer and smoking in another room somewhere, and laughing really loud.

But I digress. Try the BLT with roasted red pepper on sourdough, and ask to add avocado. Sometimes they'll have it, sometimes not, but it's really good either way. Walk out smiling and fulfilled.

Sunday morning visit in mid-July.  

Awesome scone, pretty good waffle, fabulous berry topping, superb seitan hash, absolutely disgusting iced coffee.  Off-putting cooler than thou attitude from staff, long but relatively fast-moving line.

This is probably all you need to know.

If I could send a minion to pick up baked goods/seitan hash here and coffee elsewhere, it would be the perfect arrangement.

We stopped in for baked goods on a weekday morning and the cafe was pleasantly occupied but not too full. There were a number of scone flavors available, and three scones out to try - raspberry, almond buttermilk, and something with coconut. We were informed that the first and last were sweeter. The raspberry was a bit too sweet for me, as there was a glaze on the scone. The almond buttermilk had pretty big chunks of almonds throughout. We actually decided to get a lemon cream scone. It had a nice texture and density, but was overall still a little too sweet due to the glaze, even with the tart lemon flavor. So, the scones to me seem like something great if you want a fair amount of sweetness in a big baked good.

We also tried the morning bun, which was enormous. It was flavored with cinnamon and sugar, without any citrus component, which I appreciated. The sugar did not become caramelized at the edges, which I also liked. We had a mexican wedding cookie which I thought was spot-on.

I'd be curious to try the croissants and maybe the actual meals offered. Overall I was quite impressed with the selection of baked goods and friendliness, but not pesteriness!, of the employees. A shame day old goods are only 50 cents off, but oh well.
LOVE the scones! Yum!

I've never been a huge fan of breakfast foods or bacon (I know, the horror!), but Lazy Jane's has made me a true believer! Plus, I can't even begin to rave about how cute the cafe is. It is A-dorable. With a capital A. Giant scrabble tiles, anyone? 

I only paid $8.12 for my B.L.T.P. and a mug of coffee - nice! I opted out of the potato side, but for ya'll carbo-lovers, you can add potatoes to your sandwich for a few extra bucks. Although presentation is lacking, I guess that is of little importance when your main focus is on the freshness of the food. In that category, Lazy Jane's definitely cannot be beat! (The bacon was still sizzling when I went to retrieve my sandwich from the window. Tttssssss!)

Lazy Jane's, you have truly won my heart. I can't wait to be back to try more of the menu. :9

Scones, scones, scones. Fav flavors: Maple nut and Coffee chip. Cranberry orange is pretty darn good too. Another one of the great restaurants in Madison and the hippie joint of Willy Street.
It's located in a creaky old town house. You walk in and order cafeteria style in a line by the door. 
The seating upstairs is awesome because it has more space, a sofa, and tons of children books. It reminds me of the coffee shops in Scotland where they're in rusty old homes adding an ambiance which is impossible for new buildings.

This place is exceptionally cute, a little house that you order as you walk in, tell them your name, find a seat, either downstairs or up in the "attic" and they scream it out  when the food is done....I guess, hence the "lazy"

First off - Best scone I've ever had, strawberry and peach with a lemon frosting glaze.

We were there on Sunday so we could only order brunch, but the selection just wasn't impressive or interesting or really make sense.
I had a salmon, cream cheese scramble, that was...ok.  but it was literally all this stuff mashed up and thrown on a plate for $6 or something, maybe more. 

My husband got the seitan scramble or something, that came with half a plate of eggs.  Kind of strange...it seems it seitan you'd have some kind of vegan option .. 

I don't know, again, it's really cute, and from what my cousins say - Madison lacks in the brunch department...it could be so much more interesting and eclectic, like to go with the space more.

The woman at the counter was adorable and SO friendly, but the yelling out of the names when you are upstairs is just too much...
for the 15 minutes we waited, all us at the table sat in disturbing awkward silence trying to decipher the yells coming from below.

I'd try it again for lunch or for a scone!

Visited while on business based on reviews here. Everything that has been said previously is true...charming decor, great food (cherry scone delicious), and a cozy, local-inhabited joint.
Only 3 stars because there was no wi-fi. Maybe it's just me, but I expect to have wi-fi in coffee shops everywhere. Some people might find the lack of wi-fi quaint but it is the reason I won't be back unless I stop in for a to-go order.
Scones and scramblers are delicious. The variety is large get there early for the scones before they disappear. Friendly staff, seating and parking can tough because it gets busy in the morning .

COOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOREEEEEEEEEEEEEY! That's pretty much what happens when you line up at Lazy Jane's, order some grub, grab a seat and wait for your name to be called... if you're name is Corey. It's loud and I love it. 

You know what else I also love? Blueberry scones. And blackberry scones. And pumpkin chocolate chip scones. Really I just love scones. And for a few weeks now I've been foraging for the finest, until I read some recs that lead me to believe LJ's is where it's at. And it is. They're delicate, moist, sweet but not overly so, and warped up in the micro makes it seems as though they just came outta the oven.

Add to this the fact that their other breakfast offerings are extremely reasonable for the amount of food, and you have a mighty morning stop. Bring cash though, because VISA isn't every you want to be, and the day I was there some eager eaters had trouble with the indoor ATM.

WOW. I can't believe it took me so long to try out Lazy Jane's - this place is truly a gem! With it's lime green exterior, it certainly catches your eye on Willy Street but the fact that it's built just like a house makes it easy to walk by without considering it as a restaurant. It is a casual restaurant with a relaxed, welcoming ambiance and self-serve style service. This was my second time trying to go there - be wary of their hours, as they close at 2PM! 

If you love scones, this is 100% the place to go. I've never seen any bakery in Madison that has so many kinds of scones - in fact, it's almost a little overwhelming because you'll want to order all of them and have to enact some self-restraint (THE BEST KIND OF SELF-RESTRAINT). 
- Pro tip: Go with multiple friends, order multiple scones, share them! :) They are also quite large and scones are dense in general so you can save some extra room for food!

I ordered the lemon cream scone (YUM), italian sausage omelette, and a coffee. 
- Scone: Incredible. Perfect ratio of scone to icing, the right amount of crumble in a scone, and a lovely level of sweetness. 10/10
- Italian Sausage Scramble: Comes with your choice of toast (would HIGHLY recommend wheatberry, it's a much thicker cut than regular bread and they already put butter on it for you so you don't need to feel guilty about slathering it on later), breakfast potatoes, and the scramble. This is a good amount of food overall. The scramble was one of the best I've had in Madison as well - the eggs were light, and the food didn't feel heavy or greasy like a lot of American breakfasts do. The potatoes were average, but that may have been asking too much from a solidly good dish overall. Awesome job, Lazy Jane's! 9/10

The workers are extremely friendly, the service is surprisingly fast, and there is easily accessible street parking available nearby. There is a lot of interesting art inside and this would be a place that I would feel comfortable even going to by myself and just enjoying a nice morning. Definitely stop on by if you are in the Willy Street area!

Best scones I've ever eaten.......they alone would warrant 5 stars.  Breakfast doesn't quite match up to the scones, but it's pretty good and consistent.  The scrambles (sundried tomato and bacon is my favorite) are always cooked slightly runny, which I prefer.  Portions aren't huge, but with the breakfast potatoes and choice of bread, it's adequate.  One of the nicest things about dining here is that I never feel bloated and overly greased-out.  

The place does get awfully crowded and hot, so plan your visit accordingly.  Also Lazy Jane's only accepts cash and check (ATM inside), which is kind of annoying when you want to purchase extra scones to take home or to friends!!!!!!  I understand the establishment doesn't want to pay the bank fees with credit cards and such, but it's 2012 and we're not in Chinatown or dealing with contraband!  

Definitely go for the scones, though!  They also serve them at Aldo Cafe at the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery!

This is the place that made me regret my decision to live on the west side. The space is super cute and cozy, the service friendly, the coffee delicious and the scone selection unparalleled. Though I can't say they are the best scones I've ever had (the flavors are beautiful and delicate but the texture isn't quite tender enough), they are definitely the best in town.

Lazy Jane's is a small restaurant located in a converted 2 story house. The old-fashioned furniture and abundance of knicknacks gives the distinct impression that you're eating at somebody's grandmother's house.

I've heard this place is raved about for it's breakfasts, but we went there for lunch. They had a fairly wide selection of items to choose from, all written in brightly colored chalk on blackboards behind the counter. I ordered a chai latte, strawberry scone and a cheeseburger, while my wife ordered a reuben and jasmine tea. 

We were both impressed by the scone. I expect scones to be dry and hard, but this was soft, moist, almost fluffy -- it reminded me less of what I expect of a scone and more what I'd expect from a funny-shaped muffin.

My cheeseburger was fine, if a little heavy on the lettuce for my tastes. The chai was likewise satisfactory. Niether really stood out from the crowd, but nor do I have any real complaints.

My wife not only enjoyed her tea, but stated that the reuben was the best she'd ever had.

Overall, it was decent food at a decent price in a pleasant atmosphere, so we'll probably go back.

What's wrong with you people?  If you can't find anything wrong, give it a better rating.  "We loved it" and no complaints = 5, not 4.

Lazy Jane's is one of the places I desperately miss from Madison.  I started going there when I was taking 6 AM martial arts classes nearby and was delighted to discover it on the way to work.  The eggs are, without doubt, the best in the city.  The potatos are sadly flavorless, and I'm irritated they don't give refills on milk, but other than that no complaints.  Prices are decent, being neither high nor low for the quality of food.  While the lines can be long, they move quickly and are worth the wait.

Went to Lazy Jane's for brunch this morning (around 1pm). 

Get there as early as you can! They ran out of a number of dishes and the scone selection was sparse. Also, they needed to restock the water glasses, and they ran out of forks, apparently due to a dishwasher malfunction. Eating the seitan hash with plastic cutlery is a little challenging =) 

BUT The food and atmosphere are still amazing. And I had the vanilla almond coffee. OMG! Yum!

Oh, Lazy Jane's! You are a Madison institution.

Here are the things I love about you:
-The decor make you feel like you are eating in your grandmother's living room, a ski lodge, and an art gallery all at once. 
-I like playing Scrabble while eating your delicious food.
-I enjoy the camaraderie you feel in line while waiting to order. 
-I think it is adorable that your "OPEN" sign switches to "NOPE" when you are closed.
-The food is excellent, and the lack of brunch cocktails encourages me to not waste my weekends day-drinking, which I am prone to.

Here are things that I dislike, but will accept as part of life:
-The long lines every day. I like you a lot, but sometimes I need hangover food immediately and opt to go to a way worse place across the street.
-Cash only always throws me off. I wish you would accept my plastic or at least my good intentions as currency. 
-The gluten-free toast you have is kinda gross. I used to upgrade to it out of principle, but now I just give my toast to whoever I am eating with.

Items Selected:
Vanilla Coffee, Hazelnut Coffee, Organic French Roast, Light Roast Italian
Smores Scone
Maple Walnut Scone
Blueberry Scone
Morning Bun
Almond Croissant
Blueberry Pancakes

Waking up early for a morning run around Madison it was after nearly ten miles followed by a quick shower that I made my way to kitschy and cozy Lazy Jane's Café and although I unfortunately forgot to return to the second-hand store next door before departing town my sixty minute stay at the restaurant itself was definitely a delight, the charming décor only bested by fresh baked goods and service with a smile.  Perhaps a bit "off the beaten path" and almost entirely populated by locals with counter service and self seating both upstairs and down it was to a wide variety of sandwiches, eggs, and entrees that I was tempted on arrival but focusing largely on pastry my six-part order was crafted, the first five items from the cooling racks while a daily special of blueberry studded flapjacks was readied on the griddle.  Obviously prone to overindulgence in a place with four options of coffee with limitless refills for just $1.75 it was in one cup of each that I entrusted my thirst and with both flavored options proving quite subtle I was impressed by them all, the light roast pairing best with an opening volley of three scones from which only the overly rich s'mores would prove less than textbook in texture, though flavors were all spot-on.  Underwhelmed by a croissant that was unfortunately lacking in lamination but finding reprieve in a morning bun rife with cinnamon and sugar it was finally after thirty minutes that my name was called from the kitchen and procuring my pancakes from the window before slathering them with pure maple syrup I was soon quite glad I'd only eaten half of each pastry, the bursting berries amidst fluffy buttermilk batter proving irresistible with each subsequent bite.

Ohmystars. I love the scones. I havent the faintest if anything else is good, but the scones are delicious. There is a serious Saturday morning rush, so be prepared to wait in line. The coffee could've been a bit stronger, but that's just personal preference. Cant wait to come back!

My favorite breakfast place in Madison! I always bring out-of-town guests here for a true taste of Madison.

Their scones are crazy good. I am a big fan of the lemon cream ones, but I have never been disappointed by a Lazy Jane's scone.

Their breakfast choices are all great. I usually go with a traditional eggs, bacon, and breakfast potatoes, but the scrambles and waffles are really good too!

It gets pretty busy on weekend mornings. Be prepared to wait in line if you go between 9am and noon!

And remember, it's cash only. I always forget...

Other posts have mentioned this, and they aren't lying:  the SCONES are worth the trip alone.  I ordered the Lemon Cream scone, as well as the Chorizo Scramble.  On reflection, I wish I had purchased a flight of scones.  They all looked decadent!

Great ambience -- shabby chic furniture and eclectic art on the walls.  Mismatched plates and mugs.

I went with a group of 6, and we all gave it 2 thumbs up!

But seriously:  buy a scone.

One of my fav breakfast spots! The price is right. Everything I've had is good. Notables are their pancakes, and chorizo egg scramble. Great coffee too. Employees are super fun and nice. One of the better environments out of the Mad town cafés. The cooks have a lot of fun. A visit here isn't complete without hearing your name yelled out a la Rocky yelling out for Adrienne.

This place is wonderful!  I'm not sure who Lazy Jane is but she is most certainly not the hard working baker of the gorgeous scones and pastries!  With a wonderful neighborhood and community feel, this cozy place really impressed me.  Although I was trying to be good today and just had a coffee, I can't wait to go back for a raspberry scone and peanut butter hot chocolate.

I heard great things about this place but boy do I not know my way around Madison! I was able to find this charming quaint breakfast place though. There is a parking lot but can be hard depending on the time of day. I shot over when it opened and found parking and a seat.

This is a CASH ONLY place. They have a ATM and I was glad to see the fee was NOT $6 but rather a mere $1 and change.

I found the waffle with pecans and banana intriguing and ordered it. I wasn't disappointed and even inspired a few to have a similar breakfast that morning. I picked up a variety of their scones to go. I don't have any complaints about them even when I dug into one of them 2 days later! 

They do have a penguin on a stick in the back..... Fake of course. I think it might be for their garden. Unless I'm mistaken and it's not their garden at all!

Lazy Jane's is my fav brunch spot in Madison, and I swear I have been to them all. I always get a scone and try to get one of their specials. Pancakes are great, all of their scrambles are great, waffles are great, the tofu hash is great, potatoes are great - IT iS ALL GREAT. 

I luv u Lazy Jane's.

SCONES!

A variety of scones are offered daily; favorites include the lemon cream and the berry flavors.  Plus, day old scones are only $1 each (they are still good, BTW).

Vegan options include tofu scramblers and seitan hash.  About 5 daily specials are offered, so keep an eye on the chalkboard near the register.  My favorite entree is usually a scrambler from the specials board and a scone.  Espresso beverages and several different coffees of the day are available as well.  

As for decor, it's very Willy Street-ish and casual.  As a renovated older home, seating upstairs and downstairs is a charmingly motley collection of couches and old wooden chairs.  You can usually find a few board games on the upper floor and some oddities like old magazines and kids' books.

Overall a pleasant place for casual breakfast and brunch, no fuss.

The scones here are AMAZING! Eating a blueberry scone as I write this and I love it so much. Tip: all of the fruit scones use the lemon batter as a base, so that makes them all the better! Blueberry becomes blueberry lemon and man it is GOOD!
Wonderful establishment. I imagine seats are hard to come by on weekends, but during the week this place is very comfortable.

Very interesting fresh homemade Scones.

Large breakfast portions. 

I had the Carnitas Spinich Omelette very good with baby red potatoes.
I like the different way it is set and what makes it unique, but somehow fighting for table, and the yelling of our name for kitchen uhh ,also limited  choices and cash only

We heard about the lovely scones that they make. Heads up they don't take plastic. Cash only. We didn't know that and we placed our order and we were about to pay then we found out no plastic. So we looked in the wallet and the car for cash. We were still short to pay. The owner walked by and said its no problem. That was wonderful of her. It was well worthy the embarrassment. The bakery there is wonderful. We came back and we placed our order and we made sure to have extra cash on hand so we can pay back the owner. This is place is small cozy wonderful place.

We happened upon this place unexpectedly while searching for a place to grab Easter brunch. We weren't looking for a big buffet or fancy meal, so we were happy to find out that Lazy Jane's was open.

First thing I loved: it has a very homey atmosphere and is in an old house. Although I've heard it's hard to get a table during peak times, there is a lot of seating and even an upstairs dining room.

As far as food options, they are endless. I was thrilled to grab a seitan scramble. You get to pick from a variety of bread (seriously, there's 7 or so options available each day) for your side, which is another added bonus. Veggie options, fresh bakery items, and friendly service made the ordering step a piece of cake. Disclaimer: I did not see cake as one of the fresh bakery items.

Once we sat down and indulged on our breakfast, it was amazing. We all loved our food, although it wasn't fancy. My scrambled and potatoes was a bit above the level of greasy diner food, but really tasty overall.

I wish they would be open for more than just breakfast and lunch, but they sure do a good job on those meals. I'll be back very soon!

I came in here, not expecting to find a seat, but was pleasantly surprised. Even with a line out the door (11am, Sunday), by the time we got past the cash register, the two of us actually had seating options to choose from.

The food was great, my mocha was tasty and visually attractive, and the atmosphere was comfortable. I was also surprised that, even in such tight quarters, the sound level was conducive to a comfortable discussion volume.

I will most certainly be coming back to explore the menu further.

Also, I'm not sure why folks listed it as not being wheelchair accessible. When in fact, it is. (the votes have swayed and now the data given above is accurate)
Super super cute place! It's a home that's been converted to a restaurant. Food is absolutely delicious and homemade. I felt at home coming in here. Great place.

Holy cow was this place good. We were looking for good places to eat during our Madison visit and found this one on Yelp. It is everything mentioned by others and more. I will never pass up a chance to have biskets and gravy if they look promising and when I saw they were on the specials board there was no need to look any further for my breakfast choice. Homemade biskets with cheese and chives, smothered in the most fantastic gravy ever. All the others in our party were equally pleased with their choices as well. Another standout choise was the pancakes with peaches and blueberries. Nothing else was needed on them, they were perfect as served.

Wow!  The reviews I heard and read about this Cafe were great, so I decided to give it a try.

Located on the East Side of Madison it was right on my way to the Freeway back to Milwaukee after going to the Madison Farmer's Market.

This place is a bit of a time warp, and I loved in.  Large painted wooden letters with the bakery's name took be back in time, like way back in time.

But the moment I walked in the door and saw the large glass bakery case I KNOW you made a good decision to come here.  The scones, the croissants and the biscuits are all fresh, large and enticing.  And yes, they do taste as good as they look!

I had a bacon and cheddar scones that was divine!   The small flecks of local bacon and the shreds of Wisconsin aged cheddar were in perfect proportion to the well seasoned and perfectly baked scone.

While I was waiting for my scone to be heated I checked out the kitchen.   The concept here is casual awesome.  Order and pay at the register and get your beverage and bakery at the counter.   If you order entrees there's an open window to the kitchen and you wait for yours to come up and serve yourself.

I watched pretty awesome plate sized Belgian waffles, light and fluffy omelets and  stacks of golden pancakes come out of that window.  

It really made me wish that I had the time for a full breakfast, and I will make sure that I do next time.

Because based upon my experience here there will certainly be a next time!

Scones to die for!  Breakfast is delicious and sets you up wonderfully for the rest of the day.  Only issue I have is parking.  The lot is too small and you have to park in the street, if you can find a spot close.

I made it my mission to try all the brunch spots. Every weekend it was another cafe. Algorithm was running smoothly. But then I tried Lazy Jane's. After that the process just became an every other weekend routine, with the other weekend returning to Jane's. At this point it's almost always Jane's. The process is ended and I'm not even mad. The specials and the scones are always great (hit that raspberry scone with the lemon cream dough, hit that shit).

Protip: if you're not in the mood for the potatoes or toast, you can exchange the side. Just ask! Everybody's super nice.

Cash only!

Favorite place in Madison over every category.
Good portions, very friendly, pastries were amazing. in a very unique part of Madison.
The seitan hash and eggs will make you question your carnivorous habits.  Tasty scones for the road as well.  Good luck getting a table before Jerry yells out your name with your order up.

This place has been long due on my checklist. One of the cozy places in Madison. Lot of varieties to choose from for breakfast and desserts. I didn't expect they would have a parking lot but there weren't any spots available so no worries, we still found one right on the street.

Things we ordered:
Scones: Blueberry (3.5) and the double chocolate chip with almonds (5). The scones were really tasty but they were too big for us to finish but we still enjoyed them.
Setian Hash - 4. I got it with the sour dough toast and it tasted really great but I didn't feel it was extraordinary.
Tofu Scrambler - 3.5 by the husband. He expected it to be something else but it turned out something else. I liked it though. The spices and the potatoes were tasty!
Service - as good as most places in Madison. Friendly and patient.
Price - Right for the quantity.

Overall, we will definitely visit again to try the other items on the menu. :)

Oh... And I almost forgot... They have a sort of antique store right next door. Be sure to go there. They had a lot of cute and fun home decor items...

When I think of Lazy Janes I think of a sunny Saturday morning following a visit to the farmers market!  While yes great in the winter too...I just love the cozy homey feel of this place.  It can be packed on the weekend so you need to bring your patience, but if you come with good friends the wait is part of the fun!  Baked goods are obviously amazing...their scones are some of the best I've ever had (get the raspberry if it's available) and their morning buns are phenomenal.  Their food is always good and looks like your mom was in the kitchen cooking for you...nothing overly fancy but well done and delish.  I do miss that they don't yell your name out anymore from the kitchen when your order is up...that was part of the quirky charm to me, instead you now get a pager.  All in all a great staple for fun breakfast in Madison!

Good lunch spot, amazing breakfast.

 Lunch sandwiches come with chips and greens making it a pretty good buy at $8-9 per plate. Daily specials are notable for good variety and use of quality meat. My roommate is a big fan of the scones.

Solid, funky place. I stop there for breakfast once a week becuase it's delicious. The menu is fresh, the food is well portioned, not boring and flavorful. It's in an old house, which is cool, but the tables are tiny. I've not had a bad meal in six months, so what does that tell ya? the other reviewers have pointed out their strengths - their hash is fantastic, the baked goods are a must. I bring them home to Chicago each time I go. Visit this place and support them.
neg - the cash only thing is a bit backward, i know it saves them money and I dont care, but i've seen many people in put in awkward positions becuase of it. I think its time to step up LJ and join the future and dump the cash machine - u could fit another table in the place.....
